title: TOP 10 HIDDEN GEMS IN YOUR TRACTOR MANUAL!

tasks.task: Flipping front tires to reverse directional arrow for increased tire life and better traction during backing.
subtasks: Identify front tires with directional arrows indicating travel direction.
Rotate tires such that directional arrows face forward during normal operation.
For loader-heavy operations, adjust front tires to lay lugs in reverse for increased longevity and traction when backing.

tasks.task: Proper procedure for freeing a mired machine to prevent tipping hazards.
subtasks: Assess current position and surroundings of the mired machine (tipped back possible).
Back the machine out rather than driving forward to avoid rear tire lock-up and tipping.
Unload any towed implements and dig out mud from behind the rear wheels.
Use boards or similar to provide better traction behind the rear wheels.

tasks.task: Regular maintenance checks and service intervals extension consideration.
subtasks: Check coolant annually; extend service interval to six years or 6,000 hours.
Flush and replace coolant when performing maintenance.
For regular machine upkeep, follow extended service intervals as applicable (no explicit steps, but mentioned to be aware).

tasks.task: Proper seatbelt usage in relation to Roll Over Protective Structures (ROPS) position.
subtasks: With ROPS in folded position, use seatbelt when tipping risk is lower.
Keep ROPS in the fully upright position to maximize rollover protection.
If ROPS are lowered, ensure the seatbelt is off to allow quick egress if tipping occurs (inferences drawn from the manual's recommendation).

tasks.task: Correct fuel shutoff procedure when transporting a machine on a trailer.
subtasks: Close the fuel shutoff valve before transporting.
Position the machine on the trailer such that the hood or engine cover opens from the rear.

tasks.task: Loader operation tips for optimal bucket pitch and stability.
subtasks: When leveling in reverse, keep the bucket less than 40 degrees below level to prevent edge damage.
Maximize lateral stability by adjusting rear wheel positions (up to 75 inches wide) and using weight distribution aids like duallys or ballast.
Adjust front wheels’ offset plates for narrow or wide stance as needed (but note loader incompatibility if using wide stance).

tasks.task: Safe approach and removal of material piles.
subtasks: When removing from a high pile, start by scooping the top to prevent material collapse.

For manual pile removal, enter the pile carefully, with the bucket level, especially if the pile is tall, to avoid tipping hazards (though rationale contradicts common procedure, making this a potential trick).

tasks.task: Utilizing multiple wheel positions for varying lateral stability requirements.
subtasks: Familiarize with the number of rear wheel positions available (up to eight with R-R4 tread).
Adjust wheel positions to 51 inches or 75 inches for narrowest or widest stability as needed.
Be aware that loader operation is not possible in the widest wheel position (only a note, not a blind subtask).

tasks.task: Alternative practices for tire mounting direction during specific operations (loader-intensive use).
Understanding the importance of greasing through a user-friendly system to prevent system breakdowns (grease distribution task).
subtasks: Familiarize oneself with the Rethink Greasing system's operation (plug and play, no messy plunger).
Regularly check and apply grease as part of routine maintenance.

tasks.task: Addressing ROPS fold-out safety during transport maneuvers.
Loading considerations for optimal center of gravity and floor plan usage in trailers (tipping hazards).
Alternative loader leveling technique when moving forward.
subtasks: Level the bucket when moving forward to avoid edge damage and jamming (contrasts with reverse operation where float is preferred).
